"CHARLIE" LEBER
President of the Y. M. C. A. and Dramatic Club.

of small plays by its own members. In the choice of its major
productions, it seeks only the best
in the contemporary drama.
The club was formed in January, 1919, by 12 men interested
in this type of student activity.
The first year, Bernard Shaw's
"You Never Can Tell" was produced and presented to the pnblic
four times with considerable success. With the opening of the collegiate year of 1919-20, Barrie's
"The Admirable Crichton" was
selected — a very ambitious program for so young an • organization. The matter of scenery And
properties was gone into with
great detail. The club acquired all
its own scenery, which was paihted by its members under competent supervision. This, it is felt,
is a big step in making the chit,
a permanent institution. "The
Admirable Crichton" was produced twice during the current
year and received very favorable
criticism from all who saw it. At
the close of the year, two one-act
plays, written by members of the
student body, were produced before a private audience.
Parts in the cast are open to all
members of the undergraduate
body, and to those who make the
cast with a part of 25 lines or
over membership in the club is
given. To those interested in the
producing side, the club also offers membership for exceptional
interest and ability.

It is the policy of the club to
produce only the best and only
that which offers the greatest literary value to the student. It has
never attempted musical comedy,
because it believes that in doing
so the real value of college dramatics is lost.
The club will begin next year
with only five of the old cast back.

Great opportunity is open for new
men to make parts. It is hoped
to put on a major production the
first part of the winter, rehearsals
for which will begin in tlie early
fall. It is earnestly hoped by
the officers that a large number
of freshmen will come, for it is
only by working up that the high
standard set may be maintained.

JUNE 1, 1920

This issue of THE NEWS-LETTER,
which is the final one of the year,
is being published with a twofold
purpose. Its primary and selfevident aim is the interesting of
graduates of neighboring preparatory schools in Johns Hopkins
University-and to this end more
or less minute descriptions of all
the athletic and non-athletic activities of the college as well as
its scholastic attainments are
given in this issue.
Its second and more obscure aim
is thatof interestingthose students
now at the college, who seem to
be so entirely engrossed in the
pursuit of learning as to have
failed to realize the golden oppor' tunities for the development of
body and of character which are
lying within their grasp, and of
which they may avail themselves
by coming out of their shells and
by taking some interest in college
activities.
If either of these projects is fulfilled to any degree of success,
we feel that the efforts of the editors will not have been in vain,
and that what is probably the last
issue of THE NEWS-LET-reit as a
weekly will have had its desired
result.
THE NEWS-LETTER wishes to announce that as a result of the recent competition C. Warwick Perkins, '21; Frank Smith, Jr., '21,
and Eli Frank, Jr., '22, have been
elected to THE NEws-LETTEEBoard
as reporters, and Glover Fallon,

about college work and college life
at Homewood.
The interest of a new student in
0. D. K. is, of course, anticipatory. He cannot be elected until
he is a sophomore and is not likely to win the honor until his
junior or his senior year. But the
foundation for success in college
activities is laid in the freshman
year, and it is during his first
four months at Homewood that a
student can do most to further
the ambition to wear the circle
of the 0. D. K.

"THE HULLABALOO"

11

The Johns Hopkins Hullabaloo
is the traditional year-book of the
Johns Hopkins University, and is
published annually by the graduating class. Its purpose is twofold: First, to extol the virtues
of the seniors and the Senior
Class; and, second, to present a
diary of events of the year in all
branches of undergraduate activity. It is only in a limited sense
a senior class-book. The senior
section consists of the customary

MILLARD FOARD
Editor-in-Chief of the 1920 Hullabaloo.

11

THE HOPKINS COTILLIONS

II

Amongihe most interesting features of social life at Hopkins are
the three cotillions held during the
course of each college year. Since
these dances are the only formtl
affairs given by Hopkins men for
Hopkins men and their friends,
they are usually well attended,
and owing to the limited size of
the Civil Engineering Hall, where
the dances are held, it has been
found necessary to limit the sale
of tickels to 100 couples. The first
cotillion of the year takes place
just before the Christmas holidays, the second just before Lent
and the third about the middle of
May.
The Cotillion Club, under whose
direction these dances are held,
consists of nine men, one from
each of the seven fraternities at
the University, and two non-fraternity men elected by the student
body. Each year the club elects
from among its members its two
officers, a president and a secretary-treasurer. The latter handles
the finances of the club and has
charge of the sale of tickets.
The dances are usually chaperoned by members of the faculty
and their wives or by the mothers
of the members of the Cotillion
Club. During the course of the
evening there is generally an intermission, during which some
form of refreshment is served.
During the past year the cotillions have been a great success,
both from the standpoint of the
pleasure derived by those who attended and from a financial point
of view. Since there was a considerable amount of money left
over after the last cotillion, the
club decided to give, without
charging admission, two informal
the claimants, one after the Lehigh lacrosse game and one after
the game with the University of
Toronto. The first of these has already taken place and proved to
be a great success in every way.

As it: highest award for excellence in athletics, Johns Hopkins
awards the University "H." The
wearing of this letter means a
good many things; it means that
the man has worked, and worked
hard, to learn a particular game,
often putting aside personal comfort and a natutal desire to take
timings easy so that he might uphold the name of his college and
bing victory to her colors. The
"H" stands for achievement in
clean sport; the fellow who wears
it on his sweater has done something to be mighty proud of.
The award of the "H" is made
by the Athletic Board, composed
of the students elected annually.
The regulations for awards are
as follows:

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JUNE 1, 1920.

THE MINOR SPORTS

1

The minor sports at Hopkins,
like the major ones, are on an extremely high inter-collegiate level.
Successful competition with the
best colleges in the country is
their aim, and they have succeeded admirably. At present, three
minor sports are recognized by
the General Athletic Association,
with the prospect of one or two
more being recognized in the near
future. Those recognized are:
Swimming, basket-ball and tennis.
The sports contemplated for recognition are: Boxing and wrestling.
Until 1918, only four major
sports—football, lacrosse, track
and baseball — represented the
University. There had existed,
however, independent swimming
and tennis teams, and two independent basket-ball teams, one
composed of "academs" and engineers and the other of "medicos."
The swimming team was the most
successful of these, and did a
great deal toward securing recognition for it and the other independent teams.
In 1918; during the S. A. T. C.
neriod, the usual call was issued
for candidates for these teams,
and it was decided to bend every
effort to get for these sports the
official sanction of the Athletic
Association as soon as the University got back to a normal
peace basis. Due to the untiring
efforts of those interested, all
three sports were recognized, although in that year swimming
only had a regular team.
The records of the last year
have proved the wisdom of the
step. Formerly, during the winter months, athletics at Hopkins
have been allowed to drag, but
this year they surely have not.
From January 10, when the swimmers beat Lehigh, 36 to 32, in a
very close meet, till the end of
March, when the basket-ball team
came through with a final victory,
there was never a week that
elapsed when one of the teams
was not seen in action; and
'throughout the spring the tennis
team has received all the support it could desire.
The interest that these sports
have created is scarcely less than
that created by the major sports.
When the swimming team came
home from the Middle States Individual Championships with second place out of nine colleges
entered, and a week later when
they trounced Washington and
Lee, 55 to 15, they were royally
received. And when the basketball team bowed to Princeton in
one of the closest matches ever
Seen here, the' Fifth Regiment Armory was crowded with more than
a thonsand spectators.
But next year the prospects are
even brighter. The swimming
team has returning seven letter
men, and with an early start and

Y. M. C. A.

DEBATING

The Y. M. C. A. at Hopkins is
one of the most active organizations at the University. It maintains the Barn, or Student Activities Building, and thus provides a
general lounging-room and meeting place for the students.
One of its most useful tasks is
the finding of board and lodging
for the many out-of-town students. Last fall it seemed next to
impossible to find room and board
in the vicinity of the University,
but by sticking to the job day and
night, the "Y" was able to provide
places for over two hundred and
fifty students and faculty members.
At the opening of the college
year, the "Y" gives a handbook to
each student at the University,
which contains all necessary information to enable the men to get
located in their new environment,
and also giving an outline of the
various activities, with their headquarters.
The Y. M. C. A. gives annually
a freshman reception, to which all
students are invited. After the
addresses are over and refreshments disposed of, it is the custom for the freshmen and sophomores to have their first "scrap."
The class who throws the largest
number of opponents into the pon 1
in front of the Barn is the winner.
The "pep" for the rest of the year
starts here.
Members of the "Y" teach night
courses for foreigners. This year
40 students taught the English
language and the fundamentals of
American citizenship to foreigners
in their classes two nights a week,
while 10 others have been engage]
in scout and club work with boys.
The "17" also provides entertainment for foreign students, and its
deputation team speaks in many
of the smaller churches around
the city.

Debating and oratory have always been popular at Hopkins.
The debating season is generally
commenced by the annual freshman-sophomore debate, followed
soon after by the annual junior.
seniorcontest: The winners of
the first are given small individual
prizes, while the winning team in
the second contest is given a fiftydollar prize in books, known as the
Adams' prize.
The triangle debate composed
of Washington and Lee, the University of North Carolina and
Hopkins is usually held some
time in the early spring. The
members of the teams representing the University seal are given
the 'Varsity seal for debating.
In the field of oratory, the
Adams Prize for Public Speaking
is open to all sophomores, and the
Tocqueville Contest, open to all
students at the University, offer
an attractive oportunity to those
interested in oratory. The Adams' prize is given for the best delivery of some well-known speech,
while the Tocqueville medal is
given to the man who delivers the
best original paper on some phase
of French politics.

(Continued on pae-e 72, col. 3)

the expert coaching of Mr. Henry,
our new coach, Hopkins expects
to win the Eastern Collegiate
Swimming Association Championship. The basket-ball team will
lose but two men, and it is expected that with better facilities
for practice and consequently better teamwork all former records
for games won will be broken.
Tennis, with its team intact, can
safely be counted on to have another banner season.
With these safe prospects and
with the wealth of new material
bound to come to the University
next fall, everything seems to
point to the biggest year, athletically. in the history of Hopkins.

R. O. T. C.
The Johns Hopkins Unit of the
Reserve Officers Training Corps
closed an unusually successful and
profitable year with the competitive drill for the "Company Cup"
last Thursday, May 27. Company
A, under Cadet Captain L. J.
Smith, was awarded the coveted
prize by a unanimous vote of the
judges after a drill in close and
extended order in competition
with Companies B and C. Captain Ellis expressed his gratitude
at the spirit shown by members of
the unit in the trying days of inspection for the distinguished list.
Lieutenant-Colonel Gerry presented the cup to Cadet Captain
Smith, who was given a mighty
Hullabaloo by his company after
dismissal.
That the season has been a successful one for the Johns Hopkins
Unit may be seen by looking over
the history for the year. The unit
began the term last fall under
Major _George R. Guild, who retired on December 15, 1919, and
was succeeded by Lieut.-Col. Olin
0. Ellis, on overseas man and a
West Pointer. At the start a drive
was made for new members, which
was especially effective owing to
the rumor that Johns Hopkins
would be made the model infantry
unit of the United States. By October 31, when the enlistments
(for the course is entirely voluntary) had ceased the battalion
numbered 176 students.
About the end of November the
Military Department procured
some reels of instruction films,
which were shown thereafter on
Thursdays throughout the winter.
These moving pictures were generally very interesting and were
often supplemented by lectures
from men well qualified to speak,
such as Brigadier-General Smith
and Lieutenant-Colonel Gary.
December 3 was the date of the
first inspection. The District Inspector, Colonel Thayer, was the
inspecting officer, and his subsequent report was highly commendatory to Johns Hopkins. On
March 11 Colonel Bull inspected
the battalion and recommended
that it be re-inspected—this time
for a possible place among the 15
"distinguished institutions" of the
country. It was in March, also,
that the Lake Montebello region
was chosen as a sector for field exercises and first used as such. In
this month, moreover, signallers,
machine gunners and automatic
riflemen were organized and began
to specialize in these three special
branches of the military work.
The Professor of Military
Science and Tactics had had as
assistants during the year Regt.
Sgt.-Major E. Grummon and Chief
Musician A. Warnecke, Ret. To
this staff was now added First
Sergt. W. J. Flemming, who has
seen more than 30 years' service
in the army.

At its final meeting for the year
1919-20, held at the Johns Hopkins Club last Thursday evening,
the chapter of "The Scabbard and
Blade" of this University elected
to honorary membership President Goodnow and initiated the
new members chosen from next
year's list of cadet officers of the
R. 0. T. C. The initiates were
Cadet Major F. C. Chisholm, Captains T. A. Hubbard, B. F. Sollers and J. G. Douglas, and Cadet
Lieutenants T. L. Berry, Jr., L.
W. Call, R. B. Smith, E. H. Shaw
and G. A. Lippy.
At the dinner that preceded the
ceremonies, Capt. Enoch Gary and
Capt. 0. 0. Ellis spoke on the future of the R. 0. T. C. in the
colleges of the country, and of
the growing interest being
aroused in military circles in the
new type of course being given
at Johns Hopkins, as instituted
by Major Guild. Captain Ellis
complimented the chapter upon
the work that it has accomplished
this year, and outlined a program
that it may adopt for its future
efforts. Cadet Lieutenant F. H.
Townsend described the aims of
the society in promoting efficiency
in the unit and good fellowship
among the members, the development of the highest personal
qualities of the officers to be graduated, the forming of closer relations with other institutions giving military training, and the fostering of national patriotism in
general. Cadet Captain Breese
outlined briefly the history of the
society and of the Johns Hopkins
company, and delivered the
charge of next year's work in the
R. 0. T. C. to the new officers.
C. F. Chisholm and T. A. Hub- •
bard replied on behalf of next
year's officers.
A resolution was passed to recognize in a general order the labors of Cadet Captains Harold
Merscereau and H. B. Shaw, and
Cadet Lieutenant Richard T. Cox
in giving up their time in the
instruction of the R. 0. T. C.
unit this year.
Captain Ellis began early in the
spring to get the unit in shape for
the "distinguished" inspection
which took place May 12 and 13.
The inspectors were Col. William
T. Merry, Major Emory Smith,
Capt. H. T. Bull and Capt. T. L.
Crystal. May 12 was taken up
with the inspection of equipment
and drill facilities. On the morning of May 13 the personnel of the
battalion was rigidly inspected in
its theoretical and practical work,
and in the afternoon a field problem was executed before the inspectors.
The latter expressed 'much
pleasure in the condition of the

President of the Y. M. C. A. and Dramatic Club.

of small plays by its own members. In the choice of its major
productions, it seeks only the best
in the contemporary drama.
The club was formed in January, 1919, by 12 men interested
in this type of student activity.
The first year, Bernard Shaw's
"You Never Can Tell" was produced and presented to the pnblic
four times with considerable success. With the opening of the collegiate year of 1919-20, Barrie's
"The Admirable Crichton" was
selected — a very ambitious program for so young an • organization. The matter of scenery And
properties was gone into with
great detail. The club acquired all
its own scenery, which was paihted by its members under competent supervision. This, it is felt,
is a big step in making the chit,
a permanent institution. "The
Admirable Crichton" was produced twice during the current
year and received very favorable
criticism from all who saw it. At
the close of the year, two one-act
plays, written by members of the
student body, were produced before a private audience.
Parts in the cast are open to all
members of the undergraduate
body, and to those who make the
cast with a part of 25 lines or
over membership in the club is
given. To those interested in the
producing side, the club also offers membership for exceptional
interest and ability.

JUNE 1, 1920

This issue of THE NEWS-LETTER,
which is the final one of the year,
is being published with a twofold
purpose. Its primary and selfevident aim is the interesting of
graduates of neighboring preparatory schools in Johns Hopkins
University-and to this end more
or less minute descriptions of all
the athletic and non-athletic activities of the college as well as
its scholastic attainments are
given in this issue.
Its second and more obscure aim
is thatof interestingthose students
now at the college, who seem to
be so entirely engrossed in the
pursuit of learning as to have
failed to realize the golden oppor' tunities for the development of
body and of character which are
lying within their grasp, and of
which they may avail themselves
by coming out of their shells and
by taking some interest in college
activities.
If either of these projects is fulfilled to any degree of success,
we feel that the efforts of the editors will not have been in vain,
and that what is probably the last
issue of THE NEWS-LET-reit as a
weekly will have had its desired
result.

"THE HULLABALOO"

11

The Johns Hopkins Hullabaloo
is the traditional year-book of the
Johns Hopkins University, and is
published annually by the graduating class. Its purpose is twofold: First, to extol the virtues
of the seniors and the Senior
Class; and, second, to present a
diary of events of the year in all
branches of undergraduate activity. It is only in a limited sense
a senior class-book. The senior
section consists of the customary

MILLARD FOARD
Editor-in-Chief of the 1920 Hullabaloo.

11

THE HOPKINS COTILLIONS

II

Amongihe most interesting features of social life at Hopkins are
the three cotillions held during the
course of each college year. Since
these dances are the only formtl
affairs given by Hopkins men for
Hopkins men and their friends,
they are usually well attended,
and owing to the limited size of
the Civil Engineering Hall, where
the dances are held, it has been
found necessary to limit the sale
of tickels to 100 couples. The first
cotillion of the year takes place
just before the Christmas holidays, the second just before Lent
and the third about the middle of
May.
The Cotillion Club, under whose
direction these dances are held,
consists of nine men, one from
each of the seven fraternities at
the University, and two non-fraternity men elected by the student
body. Each year the club elects
from among its members its two
officers, a president and a secretary-treasurer. The latter handles
the finances of the club and has
charge of the sale of tickets.
The dances are usually chaperoned by members of the faculty
and their wives or by the mothers
of the members of the Cotillion
Club. During the course of the
evening there is generally an intermission, during which some
form of refreshment is served.
During the past year the cotillions have been a great success,
both from the standpoint of the
pleasure derived by those who attended and from a financial point
of view. Since there was a considerable amount of money left
over after the last cotillion, the
club decided to give, without
charging admission, two informal
the claimants, one after the Lehigh lacrosse game and one after
the game with the University of
Toronto. The first of these has already taken place and proved to
be a great success in every way.

class history and individual writeups, enlivened by pages of individual snap-shots and cartoons.
The book is introduced by numerous beautiful views of the campus
and buildings, followed by a number of pictures and drawings of
the faculty, together With a critical appreciation of their respective merits.
After the Senior Class pages,
pictures, write-ups and individual
snap-shots of the Junior, Sophomore and Freshman Classes are
inserted, thus bringing to a close
the first main division of the Hullabaloo. The second division is
devoted to pictures, cartoons and
write-ups of the numerous nonathletic student activities, such

As it: highest award for excellence in athletics, Johns Hopkins
awards the University "H." The
wearing of this letter means a
good many things; it means that
the man has worked, and worked
hard, to learn a particular game,
often putting aside personal comfort and a natutal desire to take
timings easy so that he might uphold the name of his college and
bing victory to her colors. The
"H" stands for achievement in
clean sport; the fellow who wears
it on his sweater has done something to be mighty proud of.
The award of the "H" is made
by the Athletic Board, composed
of the students elected annually.
The regulations for awards are
as follows:

the qualifications of each candidate for the honor ,in question.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, JUNE 1, 1920.

THE MINOR SPORTS

1

The minor sports at Hopkins,
like the major ones, are on an extremely high inter-collegiate level.
Successful competition with the
best colleges in the country is
their aim, and they have succeeded admirably. At present, three
minor sports are recognized by
the General Athletic Association,
with the prospect of one or two
more being recognized in the near
future. Those recognized are:
Swimming, basket-ball and tennis.
The sports contemplated for recognition are: Boxing and wrestling.
Until 1918, only four major
sports—football, lacrosse, track
and baseball — represented the
University. There had existed,
however, independent swimming
and tennis teams, and two independent basket-ball teams, one
composed of "academs" and engineers and the other of "medicos."
The swimming team was the most
successful of these, and did a
great deal toward securing recognition for it and the other independent teams.
In 1918; during the S. A. T. C.
neriod, the usual call was issued
for candidates for these teams,
and it was decided to bend every
effort to get for these sports the
official sanction of the Athletic
Association as soon as the University got back to a normal
peace basis. Due to the untiring
efforts of those interested, all
three sports were recognized, although in that year swimming
only had a regular team.
The records of the last year
have proved the wisdom of the
step. Formerly, during the winter months, athletics at Hopkins
have been allowed to drag, but
this year they surely have not.
From January 10, when the swimmers beat Lehigh, 36 to 32, in a
very close meet, till the end of
March, when the basket-ball team
came through with a final victory,
there was never a week that
elapsed when one of the teams
was not seen in action; and
'throughout the spring the tennis
team has received all the support it could desire.
The interest that these sports
have created is scarcely less than
that created by the major sports.
When the swimming team came
home from the Middle States Individual Championships with second place out of nine colleges
entered, and a week later when
they trounced Washington and
Lee, 55 to 15, they were royally
received. And when the basketball team bowed to Princeton in
one of the closest matches ever
Seen here, the' Fifth Regiment Armory was crowded with more than
a thonsand spectators.
But next year the prospects are
even brighter. The swimming
team has returning seven letter
men, and with an early start and

Y. M. C. A.

DEBATING

The Y. M. C. A. at Hopkins is
one of the most active organizations at the University. It maintains the Barn, or Student Activities Building, and thus provides a
general lounging-room and meeting place for the students.
One of its most useful tasks is
the finding of board and lodging
for the many out-of-town students. Last fall it seemed next to
impossible to find room and board
in the vicinity of the University,
but by sticking to the job day and
night, the "Y" was able to provide
places for over two hundred and
fifty students and faculty members.
At the opening of the college
year, the "Y" gives a handbook to
each student at the University,
which contains all necessary information to enable the men to get
located in their new environment,
and also giving an outline of the
various activities, with their headquarters.
The Y. M. C. A. gives annually
a freshman reception, to which all
students are invited. After the
addresses are over and refreshments disposed of, it is the custom for the freshmen and sophomores to have their first "scrap."
The class who throws the largest
number of opponents into the pon 1
in front of the Barn is the winner.
The "pep" for the rest of the year
starts here.
Members of the "Y" teach night
courses for foreigners. This year
40 students taught the English
language and the fundamentals of
American citizenship to foreigners
in their classes two nights a week,
while 10 others have been engage]
in scout and club work with boys.
The "17" also provides entertainment for foreign students, and its
deputation team speaks in many
of the smaller churches around
the city.

Debating and oratory have always been popular at Hopkins.
The debating season is generally
commenced by the annual freshman-sophomore debate, followed
soon after by the annual junior.
seniorcontest: The winners of
the first are given small individual
prizes, while the winning team in
the second contest is given a fiftydollar prize in books, known as the
Adams' prize.
The triangle debate composed
of Washington and Lee, the University of North Carolina and
Hopkins is usually held some
time in the early spring. The
members of the teams representing the University seal are given
the 'Varsity seal for debating.
In the field of oratory, the
Adams Prize for Public Speaking
is open to all sophomores, and the
Tocqueville Contest, open to all
students at the University, offer
an attractive oportunity to those
interested in oratory. The Adams' prize is given for the best delivery of some well-known speech,
while the Tocqueville medal is
given to the man who delivers the
best original paper on some phase
of French politics.

the expert coaching of Mr. Henry,
our new coach, Hopkins expects
to win the Eastern Collegiate
Swimming Association Championship. The basket-ball team will
lose but two men, and it is expected that with better facilities
for practice and consequently better teamwork all former records
for games won will be broken.
Tennis, with its team intact, can
safely be counted on to have another banner season.
With these safe prospects and
with the wealth of new material
bound to come to the University
next fall, everything seems to
point to the biggest year, athletically. in the history of Hopkins.

R. O. T. C.
The Johns Hopkins Unit of the
Reserve Officers Training Corps
closed an unusually successful and
profitable year with the competitive drill for the "Company Cup"
last Thursday, May 27. Company
A, under Cadet Captain L. J.
Smith, was awarded the coveted
prize by a unanimous vote of the
judges after a drill in close and
extended order in competition
with Companies B and C. Captain Ellis expressed his gratitude
at the spirit shown by members of
the unit in the trying days of inspection for the distinguished list.
Lieutenant-Colonel Gerry presented the cup to Cadet Captain
Smith, who was given a mighty
Hullabaloo by his company after
dismissal.
That the season has been a successful one for the Johns Hopkins
Unit may be seen by looking over
the history for the year. The unit
began the term last fall under
Major _George R. Guild, who retired on December 15, 1919, and
was succeeded by Lieut.-Col. Olin
0. Ellis, on overseas man and a
West Pointer. At the start a drive
was made for new members, which
was especially effective owing to
the rumor that Johns Hopkins
would be made the model infantry
unit of the United States. By October 31, when the enlistments
(for the course is entirely voluntary) had ceased the battalion
numbered 176 students.
About the end of November the
Military Department procured
some reels of instruction films,
which were shown thereafter on
Thursdays throughout the winter.
These moving pictures were generally very interesting and were
often supplemented by lectures
from men well qualified to speak,
such as Brigadier-General Smith
and Lieutenant-Colonel Gary.
December 3 was the date of the
first inspection. The District Inspector, Colonel Thayer, was the
inspecting officer, and his subsequent report was highly commendatory to Johns Hopkins. On
March 11 Colonel Bull inspected
the battalion and recommended
that it be re-inspected—this time
for a possible place among the 15
"distinguished institutions" of the
country. It was in March, also,
that the Lake Montebello region
was chosen as a sector for field exercises and first used as such. In
this month, moreover, signallers,
machine gunners and automatic
riflemen were organized and began
to specialize in these three special
branches of the military work.
The Professor of Military
Science and Tactics had had as
assistants during the year Regt.
Sgt.-Major E. Grummon and Chief
Musician A. Warnecke, Ret. To
this staff was now added First
Sergt. W. J. Flemming, who has
seen more than 30 years' service
in the army.

At its final meeting for the year
1919-20, held at the Johns Hopkins Club last Thursday evening,
the chapter of "The Scabbard and
Blade" of this University elected
to honorary membership President Goodnow and initiated the
new members chosen from next
year's list of cadet officers of the
R. 0. T. C. The initiates were
Cadet Major F. C. Chisholm, Captains T. A. Hubbard, B. F. Sollers and J. G. Douglas, and Cadet
Lieutenants T. L. Berry, Jr., L.
W. Call, R. B. Smith, E. H. Shaw
and G. A. Lippy.
At the dinner that preceded the
ceremonies, Capt. Enoch Gary and
Capt. 0. 0. Ellis spoke on the future of the R. 0. T. C. in the
colleges of the country, and of
the growing interest being
aroused in military circles in the
new type of course being given
at Johns Hopkins, as instituted
by Major Guild. Captain Ellis
complimented the chapter upon
the work that it has accomplished
this year, and outlined a program
that it may adopt for its future
efforts. Cadet Lieutenant F. H.
Townsend described the aims of
the society in promoting efficiency
in the unit and good fellowship
among the members, the development of the highest personal
qualities of the officers to be graduated, the forming of closer relations with other institutions giving military training, and the fostering of national patriotism in
general. Cadet Captain Breese
outlined briefly the history of the
society and of the Johns Hopkins
company, and delivered the
charge of next year's work in the
R. 0. T. C. to the new officers.
C. F. Chisholm and T. A. Hub- •
bard replied on behalf of next
year's officers.
A resolution was passed to recognize in a general order the labors of Cadet Captains Harold
Merscereau and H. B. Shaw, and
Cadet Lieutenant Richard T. Cox
in giving up their time in the
instruction of the R. 0. T. C.
unit this year.
Captain Ellis began early in the
spring to get the unit in shape for
the "distinguished" inspection
which took place May 12 and 13.
The inspectors were Col. William
T. Merry, Major Emory Smith,
Capt. H. T. Bull and Capt. T. L.
Crystal. May 12 was taken up
with the inspection of equipment
and drill facilities. On the morning of May 13 the personnel of the
battalion was rigidly inspected in
its theoretical and practical work,
and in the afternoon a field problem was executed before the inspectors.
The latter expressed 'much
